block.name: preface
block.docTitle: An Act of Parliament to make provision for the contents of, and for revisions of, the Laws of Kenya and for matters connected therewith

toc.tocItem: THE REVISION OF THE LAWS ORDER, 1980
THE REVISION OF THE LAWS ORDER, 1981
THE REVISION OF THE LAWS ORDER, 1983
3 Laws of Kenya to continue in existence.
5 Acts omitted from Laws of Kenya.
6 Method of compiling Laws of Kenya.

xhtml:td.xhtml:p: The Laws of Kenya directed to come into force on the 10th December, 1962.
The First annual supplement to the Laws of Kenya directed to come into force on the 18th November, 1963.
The Second annual supplement to the Laws of Kenya directed to come into force on the 1st November, 1966.
The Third annual supplement to the Laws of Kenya directed to come into force on the 11th March, 1968.
The Fourth annual supplement to the Laws of Kenya directed to come into force on the 1st September, 1970.
The Fifth annual supplement to the Laws of Kenya directed to come into force on the 17th October, 1972.
The Sixth annual supplement to the Laws of Kenya directed to come into force on the 31st August, 1974.
The Seventh annual supplement to the Laws of Kenya directed to come into force on the 1st July, 1977.
The Eighth annual supplement to the Laws of Kenya directed to come into force on the 18th September, 1978.

The Ninth annual supplement to the Laws of Kenya directed to come into force on the 3rd September, 1979.
An additional supplement to the Ninth annual supplement to the Laws of Kenya directed to come into force on the 1st October, 1979.

xhtml:p.xhtml:i: These orders are dealt with by means of instructions under the several Chapters affected.

section.heading: SECTION THE REVISION OF THE LAWS ORDER, 1980
SECTION THE REVISION OF THE LAWS ORDER, 1981
SECTION THE REVISION OF THE LAWS ORDER, 1983

xhtml:div.xhtml:p: THE REVISION OF THE LAWS ORDER, 1983
1. This Order may be cited as the Revision of the Laws Order, 1983.
2. The twelfth annual supplement :to the Laws of Kenya prepared under section 7 of :the Act shall come into force on 28th February, 1983.
DIRECTIONS FOR USE OF NEW SUPPLEMENT
1. (1) The twelfth (1982) annual supplement comprises the follow­ing booklets which should be inserted in appropriate sequence in the volumes of the Laws­
(a) Chapter 20, which is incorporated in the Laws of Kenya for the first time;
(c) a new revised accumulative index containing a complete noter-up of the Laws of Kenya as at 1st January, 1982, and including a supplement to the chronological table;
(d) a new revised table of contents including a separate table of omitted Acts.
(2) All of the new revised editions referred to in subparagraph (1) are up to date as at 1st January, 1982.
2. As the new booklets are inserted into the volumes the follow­ing booklets should be removed and stored for future reference -
(a) Chapters 118 and 125 which have been repealed;
(b) Chapters 346 and 493A which have been newly revised and re­published with new Chapter numbers;
(d) the old table of contents and index.
3. The Government. Printer will supply the 1982 supplement complete at a total cost of Sh. 989.
4. The opportunity should also be taken when inserting and extracting booklets W check whether each set of the laws is up to date This can be done in the following manner­

(a) check that the contents of the thirteen volumes tally with the 1982 edition of the table of contents supplied as par of the 1982 supplement the actual chapters in each indivi­dual volume should be as nearly as possible within the rang( of chapter numbers specified on the card printed on the spine;

(b) any chapters not specified in the 1982 edition of the table of contents will be found to contain laws which have been repealed or replaced, have become spent or have been republished under a new chapter number, and should accordingly be removed from the volumes;

(c) once the Chapters have been checked against the table o contents reference should then be made to the index to check that each Chapter is the latest, and therefore the current edition; the year of last revision is printed in the third column of Part I of the index.
5. Where Chapters are found to be missing, or to be outdated editions, replacements should be ordered from the Government Printer.

section.heading: SECTION THE LAWS OF KENYA (RECTIFICATION) ORDER, 2005

xhtml:div.xhtml:p: SPECIAL ISSUE 3
LEGAL NOTICE No. 2
THE REVISION OF THE LAWS ACT (Cap. 1)
IN EXERCISE of the powers conferred by section 13 of the Revision of the Laws Act, the Attorney-General makes the following Order:
THE LAWS OF KENYA (RECTIFICATION) ORDER, 2005
1. This Order may be cited as the Laws of Kenya (Rectification) Order, 2005.

2. The errors specified in the second column of the Schedule, appearing in the sections of the Treaty for the Establishment of the East African Community Act (No. 2 of 2000) specified in the first column, are rectified in the manner specified in the third column.
SCHEDULE

xhtml:td.xhtml:p: Omission of the words "of the Community".
Insert the words "of the Community" immediately after the word "Gazette".
Omission of the words "of the Community".
Insert the words "of the Community" immediately after the word"Gazette".

xhtml:div.xhtml:p: Made on the 29th December, 2004.
S. A. WAKO,

foreign.xhtml:div: 1. This Act may be cited as the Revision of the Laws Act.

section.heading: SECTION 3 Laws of Kenya to continue in existence.

foreign.xhtml:div: 3. Subject to this Act, the Laws of Kenya as amended and kept up to date at the commencement of this Act shall continue in existence.

section.heading: SECTION 4 Contents of Laws of Kenya.
SECTION 5 Acts omitted from Laws of Kenya.

xhtml:div.xhtml:p: 5. There may be omitted from the Laws of Kenya -
(a) annual appropriation Acts;
(b) specific loan or specific loan guarantee Acts;

(c) any Act which is in the opinion of the Attorney-General -
(i) of temporary effect; or
(ii) of local or limited application; or
(iii) of application only to a time past;
(d) any Constitution of Kenya (Amendment) Act or provision in such Act which does not become incorporated in the Constitution;
(e) any Act which in the opinion of the Attorney-General ought to be temporarily omitted by reason of -
(i) proposed substantial amendments to the Act or subsidiary legislation made thereunder; or
(ii) the proposed making of a substantial quantity of new subsidiary legislation thereunder;
(iii) the Act in question not yet being in force at the time of a given revision.

section.heading: SECTION 6 Method of compiling Laws of Kenya.

foreign.xhtml:div:
6. (1) The Laws of Kenya shall be printed in the form of booklets, a separate booklet being printed for -
(a) the Constitution and any subsidiary legislation made thereunder;
(b) each Act and the subsidiary legislation made thereunder;
(c) each piece of foreign legislation applied to Kenya,
included in the Laws by virtue of section 4.
Provided that where the Attorney-General deems it expedient any legislation referred to in this subsection may be printed in more than one booklet.
(2) Every booklet shall contain on the front page thereof the expressions "Laws of Kenya" and "Revised Edition..... Printed and Published by the Government Printer Nairobi" or "printed and published by...... (name of printer) with the Authority of the Attorney-General" and on every other page thereof the expression "Rev. . . . " with the appropriate year of revision inserted in each case.
(3) In addition to the publication of the Laws of Kenya in the manner prescribed in foregoing provisions of this section, a Printer, referred to in subsection (2), may also publish the Laws of Kenya in electronic form.

xhtml:div.xhtml:p: Provided that more that one supplement may be prepared under this section in respect of any one year, or a supplement may be prepared in respect of more than one year, where the Attorney-General considers it expedient; and where a second or subsequent supplement is prepared in respect of any one year, it may contain all or any of the revised editions specified in this section.

section.heading: SECTION 9 Copies of annual supplements to be kept for record.

foreign.xhtml:div:
9. (1) The Attorney-General shall cause three sets of each annual supplement to be bound in a permanent manner.
(2) The sets of supplements so bound shall be certified by the Attorney-General on the title page thereof to be true copies of the supplement prepared by him and shall thereafter be delivered to and retained for the purposes of record by the Clerk of the National Assembly, the Registrar of the High Court and the Attorney-General respectively.

section.heading: SECTION 10 Bringing into force of annual supplement.

foreign.xhtml:div:
10. (1) When the annual supplement has been printed the Attorney-General shall, by order in the Gazette, direct that the supplement shall come to force on such day as he shall specify and shall annex to such order detailed directions for incorporation of the supplement into Laws of Kenya.
(2) Where an annual supplement is brought into force under this section and contains a revised edition of any law, that revised edition shall supersede any previous edition of that law whether previously contained in the Laws of Kenya or not.

section.heading: SECTION 11 Construction of references to laws in Laws of Kenya.

foreign.xhtml:div: 11. Where, in any written law or in any instrument or document of whatever kind, reference is made to any written law which is affected by or under the operation of this Act, such reference shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be deemed to be a reference to the corresponding written law in the Laws of Kenya, and all cross-references in any such law, instrument or document shall, where they are affected by or under the operation of this Act, be read and construed with such modifications as circumstances require.

section.heading: SECTION 12 Presumption of authenticity of copies of Laws of Kenya.

foreign.xhtml:div: 12. Every volume, and every booklet, purporting to be a part of the Laws of Kenya and bearing the expressions prescribed by section 6 (2) shall be presumed to be a part of the Laws of Kenya until the contrary is proved.

13. The Attorney-General may, by order in the Gazette, rectify any clerical or printing error appearing in the Laws of Kenya, or rectify in a manner not inconsistent with the powers of revision conferred by this Act any other error so appearing.
Short title.

Interpretation.
